}} '''Nuevo LeÃ³n''' ({{IPA-es|ËnweÎ²o leËon}}, officially ''Estado Libre y Soberano de Nuevo LeÃ³n'' ({{lang-en|Free and Sovereign State of New Leon}}) is one of the 31 states which, with the [[Mexico City|Federal District]], comprise the [[Political divisions of Mexico|32 Federal Entities]] of [[Mexico]]. It is divided in [[Municipalities of Nuevo LeÃ³n|51 municipalities]] and its capital city is [[Monterrey]]. It is located in [[Northeastern Mexico]]. It is bordered by the states of [[Tamaulipas]] to the north and east, [[San Luis PotosÃ­]] to the south, and [[Coahuila]] to the west. To the north, Nuevo LeÃ³n has a 15 kilometer (9 mi) stretch of the [[U.S.-Mexico border]] adjacent to the [[U.S. state]] of [[Texas]]. The state was named after the [[New Kingdom of LeÃ³n]], an administrative territory of the [[Viceroyalty of New Spain]]. Besides its capital, other important cities are [[Guadalupe, Nuevo LeÃ³n|Guadalupe]], [[Santa Catarina, Nuevo LeÃ³n|Santa Catarina]], [[San NicolÃ¡s de los Garza]], and [[San Pedro Garza GarcÃ­a]], all of which are part of the [[Monterrey Metropolitan area]]. ==History== {{Main|History of Nuevo LeÃ³n}} {{See|New Kingdom of LeÃ³n}} [[Image:Monterrey Palacio del Gobierno.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The original Government Palace (State House) of Nuevo LeÃ³n]] Nuevo LeÃ³n was originally founded by [[Alberto del Canto]], although frequent raids by [[Chichimeca]]s, the [[Native Americans (Americas)|natives]] of the north, prevented the establishment of almost any permanent settlements. Subsequent to the failure of del Canto to populate [[Luis Carvajal y de la Cueva]], at the head of Portuguese and Spanish settlers, requested permission from the Spanish King to attempt to repopulate the area which would be called the [[New Kingdom of LeÃ³n]], it eventually became (along with the provinces of [[Coahuila]], [[Nuevo Santander]] and [[Texas]]) one of the Eastern Internal Provinces in Northern New Spain.Gerhard, Peter. The North Frontier of New Spain. Princeton, Princeton University Press, 1982.En los albores de la independencia: Las Provincias Internas de Oriente durante la insurrecciÃ³n de don Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla, 1810-1811. by Isidro Vizcaya Canales In the 19th century, Nuevo LeÃ³n was in a growth spurt and the bargain land deals attracted immigrants of [[Germans|German]], [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]], [[French people|French]], [[Italian people|Italian]], [[Jew]]ish and [[English-American|Anglo-American]] origin. The capital of Nuevo LeÃ³n is [[Monterrey]], the third largest city in Mexico with over four million residents. Monterrey is a modern and affluent city, and Nuevo LeÃ³n has long been one of [[Mexico]]'s most industrialized states. ==Geography== [[Image:San Nicolas Nuevo LeÃ³n.jpg|thumb|left|160px|[[La Huasteca Climbing Area|La Huasteca State Park]]]] Nuevo LeÃ³n has an extreme climate, and there is very little rainfall throughout the year. The territory covers {{convert|64220|km2|sqmi}}, and can be divided into three regions: a hot, dry region in the north, a temperate region in the mountains, and a semi-arid region in the south. The [[Sierra Madre Oriental]] mountain range affects in an important way the lay of the land forming the Galeana and Doctor Arroyo plateaus, the Iguana, Picachos, Papagayos, and Santa Clara mountain ranges, and the PilÃ³n, AscensiÃ³n, and RÃ­o Blanco valleys. As for hydrography, the [[San Juan River (Tamaulipas)|San Juan River]] supplies the El Cuchillo dam, which provides water for [[Monterrey]] and the metropolitan area. There are also the Cerro Prieto, La Boca, VaquerÃ­as, Nogalitos, and Agualeguas dams. [[Laguna de Labradores]] is a major lake in Nuevo LeÃ³n, and [[Pozo del GavilÃ¡n]] is a natural well. Both are located in the [[Galeana, Nuevo LeÃ³n|Galeana]] municipality. The flora of the region includes brush and pastures in the low regions, and pine and oak trees in the mountains. The fauna includes [[American black bear|black bear]]s, [[Cougar|mountain lions]], [[Peccary|javelinas]], [[prairie dog]]s, [[fox]]es, [[coyote]]s, and [[white-tailed deer]], along with smaller species. ==Demography== [[Image:Mexico-nuevo-leon-montemorelos-iglesia.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Church, Montemorelos, Nuevo LeÃ³n]] As of 2005, Nuevo LeÃ³n's population was about 4.1 million. Nearly 80% of the state's population resides within the Monterrey Metropolitan area. Life expectancy is high, reaching 73 years for men and no less than 79 years of age for women. On the other hand, 94% of the total population occupy urban areas, one million of which are home-owners, and 98% of which enjoy the full utilities of running water, sewer systems and electric power. Following the nation's tendency, a majority of the population identifies as being [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]]. ==Major communities== *[[Apodaca]] *[[Cadereyta JimÃ©nez]] *[[Ciudad Benito JuÃ¡rez]] *[[Doctor Arroyo]] *[[General Escobedo]] *[[Guadalupe, Nuevo LeÃ³n|Guadalupe]] *[[Linares, Nuevo LeÃ³n|Linares]] *[[Monterrey]] *[[Sabinas Hidalgo]] *[[San NicolÃ¡s de los Garza]] *[[San Pedro Garza GarcÃ­a]] *[[Santa Catarina, Nuevo LeÃ³n|Santa Catarina]] ==Education== [[File:ITESM Femsa Biotechnology Center Aulas I.jpg|thumb|Biotechnology center of the Instituto TecnolÃ³gico y de Estudios Superiores de Monterrey.]] The high quality of life that prevails across the state is reflected on statistical rates such as education, as the entity reports an almost perfect record for finished secondary education, and 13 in 100 inhabitants earn a professional degree.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} In the same line, illiteracy rates for the state are within the lowest in the nation at 2,8%, just behind the [[Mexico City|Distrito Federal]] which still leads the country in this regard.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} Institutions of higher education include: *[[Universidad AutÃ³noma de Nuevo LeÃ³n]] (UANL) *[[Instituto TecnolÃ³gico y de Estudios Superiores de Monterrey]] (ITESM) *[[TecMilenio University]] (UTM) *[[University of Montemorelos|Universidad de Montemorelos]] *[[Universidad Regiomontana]] (UR) *[[Universidad de Monterrey]] (UDEM) *[[Centro de Estudios Superiores de DiseÃ±o de Monterrey]] (CEDIM) ==Economy== [[File:Steel mill Fundidora Park.jpg|thumb|left|The Fundidora industrial park in Monterrey.]] [[File:Horno 3 ext.jpg|thumb|Altos Hornos de Mexico, Mexico's largest steel maker has its facilities in Nuevo Leon and sponsors a museum of Science and Technology.]] Highly industralized, Nuevo LeÃ³n possesses a standard of living similar to that of countries such as Croatia, Slovakia or Poland. In 2007, the per capita GDP of the state was similar to that of the Asian Tiger of South Korea and even higher than that of some European Union states such as Slovakia and Hungary. At $26,658, it was the highest GDP per capita (PPP) of any Mexican state (not counting the Federal District), and was therefore higher than the Mexican national average (2007 GDP per capita (PPP) national average was $14,119).INEGI, PoblaciÃ³n total por entidad federativa segÃºn sexo, 2000 y 2005 and PIB estatalhttp://sg.nl.gob.mx/DataNL/files%5CDNL00000431.pdf One of its municipalities, [[San Pedro Garza GarcÃ­a]], is among the richest in the country in terms of per capita income. It is also home of powerful conglomerates, such as [[Cemex]] (one of the largest construction materials firms in the world), [[Bimbo (company)|Bimbo]] (bakery and pastry), [[Gruma|Maseca]] (food and grains), [[Banorte]] (the only high-street bank in Mexico wholly owned by Mexicans), [[ALFA (Mexico)|ALFA]] (Sigma, Alestra, Nemak, Alpek and Hylsa (recently bought by Ternium), [[i-service]] (HelpDesk), [[Vitro SA]] (glass), [[FEMSA]] (Coca-Cola in Latin America), and [[CervecerÃ­a CuauhtÃ©moc Moctezuma]] (brewers of ''Sol'', ''Tecate'', ''XX'', ''Bohemia'', ''Indio'' and ''Nochebuena''). [[File:Cerveceria.cuahotemoc.monterrey.ncs.jpg|thumb|The facilities of the [[CervecerÃ­a CuauhtÃ©moc Moctezuma]] brewery in Nuevo Leon are the single largest producer of alcoholic beverages in the world.]] Nuevo LeÃ³n also boasts a rich agricultural core, called the "orange belt", which comprises the municipalities of Allende, [[Montemorelos]], [[Hualahuises]], [[General TerÃ¡n]] and [[Linares, Nuevo LeÃ³n|Linares]]. Small but productive investments have been transforming traditional harvests (mainly based on orange and cereals) into agroindustrial developments that are producing increasing revenues for the local economy. In contrast with the relative wealth of industrial Nuevo LeÃ³n and the orange belt, the Southern part of the state (municipalities of Galeana, [[Aramberri, Nuevo LeÃ³n|Aramberri]], [[Zaragoza]], [[Doctor Arroyo]] and [[Mier y Noriega]]) remains rural and less productive. Most of The South of the state is at the mercy of a very dry weather that represents a major hurdle for agriculture and livestock.
